In case it's not obvious these demographics are being chosen based on the current political realignment. White men without a college degree used to be a reliable Democrat voting bloc but are now moving rapidly to the right. Conversely college educated women are moving rapidly to the left.

It's really quite crazy watching this realignment and especially how unaware young people on reddit seem to be on it. I remember when making fun of poorly educated voters was something Republicans did to mock Democrat and now it's flipped around. Same with the general consensus online which has gone from heavily right leaning to heavily left leaning.

It's hard to counter-argue persuasion attempts you don't know are being made.  I had no clue the curated and crazy content my 76 year old mother gets.  It literally flipped her from blue to red.  And I never would have known if she hadn't slipped and repeated something that she had been targeted with.  And she clammed up when I asked her about the "fact" she had shared and where she had gotten it.  Older people, boomers, etc. aren't very good at dissecting the content they are getting.  They are of a generation that trusted news sources because they grew up on newspapers and the evening news as being largely non-partisan (Thanks Reagan).

In this data app, linear regression, classification, and a nationwide vote prediction for Trump vs. Harris were used to forecast the results of Tuesday's presidential election based on polling data. The analysis then focused specifically on swing states, with particular attention to Michigan.

Link to the data app: [https://deepnote.com/app/katkas-workspace/US-election-prediction-2024-2ab7bc78-cc32-47b8-b04b-406a6a546385](https://deepnote.com/app/katkas-workspace/US-election-prediction-2024-2ab7bc78-cc32-47b8-b04b-406a6a546385)

Presidential General Election: 2020 Polls, FiveThirtyEight ([https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2020/national/](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2020/national/))

So, I'm not exactly sure what I said that implies anything that contradicts what you said. I know amendments are for the entire Constitution. I also know that the Bill of Rights weren't done later on and that they were basically part of the original Constitution when it was first ratified in 1789, right? (Or shortly thereafter).



My point that I didn't make was that that none of the Constitution is exempt from being amended, whether it's the Bill of Rights, the original Constitution minus the Bill of Rights, or any subsequent amendments. The idea that the Founding Fathers were omniscient Gods and that none of the stuff in the Constitution nor the Bill of Rights should ever be altered is what I was arguing against.



I did not know about the Federalists and the history of the Bill of Rights being designed to protect the rights of the people, which weren't enumerated in the original constitution, nor do I know the history of the Articles of Confederation. I appreciate the insight you've added in your comment.



Maybe my comments implied something that I didn't intend, but my point was that the Constitution isn't the Bible and the Founding Fathers weren't all-knowing oracles of the future. That's literally why there's an amendment process that they came up with because they knew times would change. It's a great system to have lasted as long as it has so far.

Interesting graph, but the comments are using this to circle jerk unions and that’s a bit silly honestly. Like yeah, obviously union pay is going to be higher. In industries where it isn’t, nobody would join the union and it’d instantly have no reason to even exist. We wouldn’t see those examples on a chart. 

That doesn’t mean unions are automatically “good” and have no flaws. They have pros and cons. They’re pretty good for workers who have been in the union, bad for those who aren’t, and obviously costly for employers. They’re only VERY good for union bosses who collect dues. The way unions work is that pay for union workers is higher at the expense of pay for workers outside the union. This happens because non-union workers can’t get hired or paid as well due to the agreements created between unions and employers that force certain employers to only use union labor. Union leaders in these cases are essentially just restricting labor supply for employers, in turn driving up labor costs (in the form of higher pay) for union workers. When you factor in the dues that unions require though, the gap between non-union and union pay has to be large for it to even start to be worth it for the workers in the union, and the workers outside of the union are still worse off because they can’t compete with the same job supply. 

People on Reddit glaze unions as a blanket pro-worker thing, but they only kinda are. They’re good for workers already in a good union, bad for workers in a shitty union that don’t negotiate well but have high dues, and bad for workers not in a union. It’s not something you can say is always pro-worker.
